awd_titl_txt: Direct Injection Molding of Superstrength Metal Matrix      Composites
awd_abstract_narration: 9406800  German    Nanoparticles will be mixed with low temperature alloys to form a  heated slurry with sufficient fluidity that can be directly molded,  by using a net-shape manufacturing process.  A hybrid of  rheocasting and injection molding will be applied.  Preliminary  data are necessary to check the basic concepts and the approach,  including the proper interfacial particle-alloy properties, the  recommended synthesis method for nanoparticles, the fluidity and  corresponding thermal characteristics of the composite slurry.  The  strength of the resulted composite material should improve it the  specific powder-alloy interfacial area is larger, and the  dislocation line length between phases is smaller.  In the first  set of experiments, nanoscale iron precursor materials are low-  cost, commercially available.  If successful, the results of the  proposed exploratory research could be transferred immediately to  industry.  The approach could offer new manufacturing, materials  and design options.    The envisioned process will potentially provide new materials with  superstrengths via a low temperature, highly automated  manufacturing technology.    ***
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems
